awd_titl_txt: ACQUISITION OF A TRIBOLOGICAL FACILITY FOR THE ANALYSES OF FRICTION, WEAR, AND LUBRICATION OF GEO-SYSTEMS
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide funding to build an experimental facility dedicated to Geotribology that will focus on the friction, wear and lubrication of geo-systems, with a parallel equivalency to engineering tribology. The facility will include a tribological system of multiple integrated tools that are commercially built by engineering standards. Via this project, a new facility, GeoTrib, will be created to study the fundamentals of friction, wear, and lubrication in geological systems, from faults to the base of glaciers. The facility will allow multi-scale and multi-condition analyses of earthquake physics, fault stability, and glacial motion and will impact socio-economic issues of seismic hazard and climate change. Further, the facility will use engineering methods and standards and thus will contribute to narrowing the gap between the geoscience community of friction and wear, and the equivalent, large engineering community. GeoTrib will be an open facility for interested researchers who could conduct their experimental work with minimal support of the local team thanks to its versatile, modular design. 

Until recently, tribological techniques have not been widely applied to geological problems. The facility will utilize engineering tribological methodologies and standards for experimental studies of fundamental crustal and mantle mechanical problems that are too difficult to conduct with existing geophysics systems. GeoTrib will be used for analyses of faulting processes, earthquake physics, glacier flow, landslide creep, debris flow, stream-bed erosion, volcanic eruptions and lava flows. Potential research projects include: (1) the effects of sample scale on roughness, friction and wear; (2) the effects of water presence, water saturation, and temperature (-25 degrees C to 1,000 degrees C) on plasticity and healing rates of faults zones; (3) the dynamic friction and fluid-solid interactions at elevated temperature; (4) static and dynamic strength of bi-material faults; (5) the evolution of fault hardness with temperature, velocity, and displacement; (6) testing theoretical friction/wear/lubrication models at crustal conditions of temperature and water presence; (7) investigating brittle-ductile transition with thermally-dependent mechanisms, e.g., dislocation climb, grain-boundary-sliding, at the nanoscale; and (8) the fundamentals of ice friction and rock wear at glacier base and icy satellites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This proposed project was to acquire, install, and implement a Tribometer system, which is an experimental system commonly used in the engineering field. While typically used for testing the friction, wear, and lubrication of metals in engineering tribology, we have implemented the device to focus on friction and wear in geo-systems. Geo-systems include (but are not limited to), earthquake faults, landslides, the base of glaciers, and volcanic eruptions. After significant research and discussion with several manufacturers, we decided to acquire the Bruker Universal Mechanical Tester (UMT). The device was chosen as it offered a wide range of experimental configurations and testing conditions that greatly expanded our capability of testing friction and wear in geo-systems. Sample loading configurations include pin-on-disc, pin-on-block, and ring-on-disc. In some configurations, in-situ measurements of hardness, and immediate microscopic imaging of wear phenomena are possible. Experimental conditions include: slip-velocities of 1 micron/s to 12 meters/s, normal load up to 30 MPa, controlled environmental chambers of humidity (5-85%), temperature (from -25 degrees to 1,000 degrees Celsius), and liquid presence (variable composition). As an engineering-based system, it offers high resolution of 3D displacements and forces at high sampling rates.

The major outcome of the project has been the installation and implementation of the device, which will allow for the setup a facility for community use. Our initial discussions with potential users have focused on: ice on rock friction constitutive behavior (Zoet - University of Wisconsin Madison), determinations of slip surface hardness at room and elevated temperatures (Tesei - University of Padova), and friction constitutive behavior of material from the 2019 Ridgecrest surface rupture (Nevitt - USGS). The PI’s have focused on initiating projects related to physico-chemical processes of fault healing the role of surface roughness in frictional slip and wear. With the current and planned potential projects, the UMT system allows for experimental studies of fundamental crustal and mantle mechanical problems that are too difficult to conduct with existing experimental systems. The PI’s along with potential collaborators are well positioned to use the engineering methodology and flexibility present in the UMT system to address and inform a host of fundamental questions related to faulting processes, earthquake physics, glacier flow, landslide creep, debris flow, stream-bed erosion, and volcanic eruptions.

Over the course of the project, including acquisition and implementation, the PI’s have focused on implementing an experimental system with the flexibility to inform societal issues such as geologic hazards (i.e. earthquakes and landslides) and climate change (glacier motion and silt production). Additionally, the PI’s have worked to identify collaborators in engineering, sedimentology, glaciology, and the planetary science communities (among others). All have expressed a desired to use the system to support their research. Such a diverse group is allowed by the traditional engineering nature and vast flexibility from the environmental chambers.  This reach does not just expand the reach of the system to other senior researchers, but to undergraduate and graduate students as well. With the implemented system, the team will continue their record of rock mechanics education with undergraduates, graduates, postdoctoral scholars, and visiting scientists. To date, the machine has been introduced to two visiting undergraduate REU students (Katherine Bonsell and Mitchell Soederberg), an OU undergraduate student (David Fleenor) and a graduate student (Alex Cordero Rincon). The PI is in the process of recruiting a MS student for an experimental project based off the UMT platform. In addition to students at the University of Oklahoma, the PI has used the equipment for demonstrations for groups including, potential OU Geoscience undergraduate admissions (high school students) and students from the College of the Muscogee Nation.
